channel.title: AWS Modernization Workshop with Gitlab, Hashicorp, & Gremlin on AWS Modernization Workshop with Gitlab, Hashicorp, Gremlin
channel.description: Recent content in AWS Modernization Workshop with Gitlab, Hashicorp, & Gremlin on AWS Modernization Workshop with Gitlab, Hashicorp, Gremlin

item.title: 3.0. Add Workspace
item.description: Connect Gitlab as VCS source Switch tabs to Terraform Cloud (https://app.terraform.io/) Step 1: On Terraform Cloud, Begin Adding a New VCS Provider If you don’t already have an your organization, add organization (you can use your fistname and laster inital for example Jane Doe -> janed ) Open Terraform Cloud in your browser and navigate to the Settings > VCS Providers page for your organization. Click the “Add VCS Provider” button.

item.title: AWS Event Engine
item.description: Logging into AWS Event Engine To complete this workshop, you are provided with an AWS account via the AWS Event Engine service. A 12-digit hash will be provided to you by event staff - this is your unique access code. eg: e8476543c00e Go to https://dashboard.eventengine.run to log into AWS Event Engine. Enter your unique 12-digit hash code and choose Accept Terms & Login. Choose AWS Console, then Open AWS Console.

item.title: Cloud9
item.description: Starting AWS Cloud9 IDE AWS Cloud9 is a cloud-based integrated development environment (IDE) that lets you write, run, and debug your code with just a browser. It includes a code editor, debugger, and terminal. Cloud9 comes pre-packaged with essential tools for popular programming languages and the AWS Command Line Interface (CLI) pre-installed so you donâ€™t need to install files or configure your laptop for this workshop. Cloud9 works best with Chrome or Firefox, not Safari.

item.title: Create an SSH Key via Cloud9
item.description: Create an SSH Key From terminal: ssh-keygen Expected output: Upload your ssh key to Gitlab cat /home/ec2-user/.ssh/id_rsa.pub Expected output: Copy your key to the clipboard

item.title: 3.1. Setup Terraform Varibles
item.description: Switch to Cloud9 tab https://console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/v2/home?region=us-east-2#Instances:search=aws-cloud9 Add AWS Varibles Proceed on the Terraform Cloud tab Click Configure variables In the Environment Variables we will add three variables AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY AWS_DEFAULT_REGION set to us-east-1

item.title: AWS Workshop Account
item.description: Your account must have the ability to create new IAM roles and scope other IAM permissions. Create an account If you don’t already have an AWS account with Administrator access: create one now Once you have an AWS account, ensure you are following the remaining workshop steps as an IAM user with administrator access to the AWS account: Create a new IAM user to use for the workshop

item.title: Gitlab
item.description: Login to Gitlab If you do not already have a Gitlab account Register here If you are a exsiting user Login in here

item.title: Upload key to Gitlab
item.description: Navigate to the profile section of gitlab https://gitlab.com/profile/keys Paste the key into the textbox provided Title the key cloud9-ide-key Choose Add Key Navigate back to your project in Gitlab -> https://gitlab.com/your-username/aws-devops-workshop NOTE: Be sure to replace your-name with your gitlab username TIP: Do these step from cloud9 (Switch tabs to your cloud9 terminal)

item.title: Create Gitlab Repo
item.description: Create Gitlab Repo Create a new project at https://gitlab.com/projects/new Set the Project name to aws-devops-workshop Choose Create Project Configure Git form your Cloud9 Git global setup git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "email@domain.com" Clone your repository git clone git@gitlab.com:/aws-devops-workshop.git cd aws-devops-workshop echo "My AWS DevOps Workshop Repo" README.md git add README.md git commit -m "add README" git push -u origin master

item.title: Enable Gitlab CI
item.description: Create Gitlab CI Configuration From terminal: Get the CI config file via wget wget https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/alliances/aws/sandbox-projects/global-devops-workshop/-/raw/workshop/lab_assets/gitlab/gitlab-ci.yml -O .gitlab-ci.yml Add to git and push to repository git add .gitlab-ci.yml git commit -a -m'Enable Gitlab CI' git push

item.title: Terraform
item.description: Login to Terraform cloud If you do not already have a Terraform Cloud account Register here If you are a exsiting user Login in here Create organization name it aws-devops-workshop. If you plan on using this org long term you can use your fistname and last inital for example: (JaneDoe janed)

item.title: Gremlin
item.description: Login to Gremlin If you do not already have a Gremlin account Register here If you are a exsiting user Login in here
